<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Revenues
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
	Investment Banking
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Investment banking revenues were $10.6&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2009, representing the investment banking
	activity of Cowen Holdings for the period from November&nbsp;2, 2009
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	59
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=62,EFW="2202468",CP="COWEN GROUP, INC.",DN="1",CHK=930098,FOLIO='59',FILE='DISK121:[11ZAE1.11ZAE12801]DK12801A.;36',USER='JLAWRENA',CD='11-MAR-2011;19:26' -->
<A NAME="A2202468Z10-K_HTM_PAGE_DK12801_1_60">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A HREF="#A2202468Z10-K_HTM_BG12801A_MAIN_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<BR>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	through
	December&nbsp;31, 2009. There were no investment banking revenues in 2008 as the historic results of operations only reflect the legacy Ramius business.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
	Brokerage
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Brokerage revenues were $17.8&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2009, representing the brokerage activity of Cowen
	Holdings for the period from November&nbsp;2, 2009 through December&nbsp;31, 2009. There were no brokerage revenues in 2008 as the historic results of operations only reflect the legacy Ramius
	business.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
	Management Fees
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Management fees decreased $29.1&nbsp;million, or 41%, to $41.7&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2009 compared
	with $70.8&nbsp;million in 2008. The decrease was primarily due to the lower level of assets under management in 2009 relative to the prior year.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
	Incentive Income
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Incentive income was $1.9&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2009, compared to no incentive income for 2008. In
	addition, due to losses in 2008, many of our funds now have high-water marks such that Ramius will not earn incentive income with respect to the assets of the fund investors who suffered
	such losses in 2008 until these investors recover their
	losses. Incentive income earned in 2009 relates primarily to fees earned on one of our fund of funds products that went over its high water mark in December 2009.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
	Interest and Dividends
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Interest and dividends decreased $1.5&nbsp;million, or 76%, to $0.5&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2009,
	compared with $2.0&nbsp;million in 2008. The decrease was primarily attributable to a combination of lower average interest rates and lower average interest bearing assets in 2009 compared with
	2008.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
	Reimbursements from Affiliates
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Ramius's reimbursements from affiliates decreased $6.0&nbsp;million, or 37%, to $10.3&nbsp;million for the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2009 compared with $16.3&nbsp;million for 2008. The decrease was attributable to lower assets under management in 2009 as the Company generally limits such allocations based on a
	percentage of assets under management.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
	Other Revenue
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other revenue decreased $2.2&nbsp;million, or 31%, to $4.7&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2009 compared with
	$6.9&nbsp;million in 2008. The decrease was primarily due to the elimination of stock loan fee income as the Company exited that business in the fourth quarter of 2008, and the reduction of
	placement fee income. The Company exited the placement agent business in the third quarter of 2009.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
	Consolidated Funds Revenues
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Consolidated Funds revenues increased $4.7&nbsp;million, or 14.7%, to $36.4&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31,
	2009 compared with $31.7&nbsp;million in 2008. The increase
	was primarily attributable to an increase in the interest and dividends earned by the Enterprise Fund due to a larger concentration in fixed income securities.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	60
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=63,EFW="2202468",CP="COWEN GROUP, INC.",DN="1",CHK=274928,FOLIO='60',FILE='DISK121:[11ZAE1.11ZAE12801]DK12801A.;36',USER='JLAWRENA',CD='11-MAR-2011;19:26' -->
<A NAME="A2202468Z10-K_HTM_PAGE_DK12801_1_61">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A HREF="#A2202468Z10-K_HTM_BG12801A_MAIN_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Expenses
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
	Employee Compensation and Benefits
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Employee compensation and benefits expenses increased $11.8&nbsp;million, or 14%, to $96.6&nbsp;million for the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2009 compared with $84.8&nbsp;million in 2008. The increase was due to the impact of including two months of compensation and benefits expense associated with the legacy Cowen
	Holdings business, partially offset by lower accruals for incentive compensation and lower base salaries and benefit expense associated with a reduction in head count in 2009 compared to 2008 for the
	legacy Ramius business.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
	Interest and Dividends
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Interest and dividend expense remained substantially unchanged at $1.6&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2009
	compared to $1.8&nbsp;million for 2008. Interest expense relates primarily to interest on our credit facility.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
	General, Administrative and Other Expenses
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;General, administrative and other expenses increased $15.2&nbsp;million, or 29%, to $68.2&nbsp;million for the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2009 compared with $53.0&nbsp;million in 2008. This increase was primarily due to the inclusion of two months of activity for Cowen Holdings after the closing of the Transactions
	in 2009, professional, advisory and other fees related to the Transactions, and legal fees incurred in connection with an arbitration initiated by the Company in 2009. These increases were partially
	offset by a decrease in occupancy and equipment, as a result of the Company subleasing its former office space for the entire year ended December&nbsp;31, 2009 compared to only the final eight
	months of 2008, and a decrease in client service and business development expenses. The Company does not expect to incur additional expense in connection with the arbitration matter referenced above
	and expects that transaction related expenses, if any, to be minimal.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
	Consolidated Funds Expenses
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Consolidated Funds expenses decreased $10.7&nbsp;million, or 31.2%, to $23.6&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31,
	2009 compared with $34.3&nbsp;million in 2008. The decrease was attributable to a decrease in interest and dividend expense recognized by the Enterprise Fund due to a general decrease in interest
	rates.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
	Goodwill Impairment
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company recorded a goodwill impairment charge of $10.2&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2008. This
	non-cash charge related to the impairment of its then 50% ownership of the fund of funds business. In the fourth quarter of 2008, the Company conducted its annual goodwill impairment test
	and, due to the decline in assets under management and the resulting decline in expected management fees and incentive income, recognized an impairment. There were no goodwill impairment charges
	recorded in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2009.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
	Other Income (Loss)
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other income (loss) increased $219.3&nbsp;million to income of $18.8&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2009
	compared to a loss of $200.5&nbsp;million in 2008. The increase is a result of positive fund performance in the current year period versus negative performance in the prior year period as a result
	of the general unprecedented levels of market volatility, and liquidity constraints that began in the third quarter of 2008 and affected almost every asset class globally. As previously described, the
	Company invests its own capital primarily in the Enterprise Fund with any gains or losses from the Company's investment in the Enterprise Fund shown under Consolidated Funds for that period. The
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	61
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=6,SEQ=64,EFW="2202468",CP="COWEN GROUP, INC.",DN="1",CHK=112422,FOLIO='61',FILE='DISK121:[11ZAE1.11ZAE12801]DK12801A.;36',USER='JLAWRENA',CD='11-MAR-2011;19:26' -->
<A NAME="A2202468Z10-K_HTM_PAGE_DK12801_1_62">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A HREF="#A2202468Z10-K_HTM_BG12801A_MAIN_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<BR>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	gains
	and losses shown under Consolidated Funds reflect the consolidated total performance for such funds, and the portion of those gains or losses that are attributable to other investors is
	allocated to a non-controlling interest.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Income Taxes
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Income tax benefit increased $6.9&nbsp;million to $8.2&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2009 from
	$1.3&nbsp;million in 2008. The increase was primarily related to a tax benefit of $6.0&nbsp;million representing the Company's proportionate share of deferred tax benefits generated by the master
	fund of one of the Consolidated Funds. During the third quarter of 2009, this master fund acquired reinsurance companies in Luxembourg as part of a service program that provides reinsurance coverage
	to the master fund. In order to obtain reinsurance coverage against certain risks, this master fund, through a local subsidiary, acquired reinsurance companies in Luxembourg that had deferred tax
	liabilities. Pursuant to an Advance Tax Agreement, upon these purchases, the local subsidiary generated deferred tax assets that fully offset these liabilities, resulting in the recognition of the
	deferred tax benefit.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	(Income) Loss Attributable to Redeemable non-controlling Interests
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Income (loss) attributable to redeemable non-controlling interests increased $130.0&nbsp;million, to a gain of
	$16.2&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2009
	compared with a loss of $113.8&nbsp;million in 2008. The period over period change was the result of improved performance in certain of the Consolidated Funds.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Segment Analysis and Economic Income (Loss)
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
	Segments
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Prior to the consummation of the Transactions, the Company conducted its operations through one reportable segment, the alternative
	investment management segment, which provides management services to its hedge funds, fund of funds, real estate and other investment platforms. Following the combination of Ramius and Cowen Holdings,
	the Company conducts its operations through two segments: an alternative investment management segment and a broker-dealer segment. The Company's alternative investment management segment currently
	includes its hedge funds, fund of funds, real estate and other investment platforms businesses, as well as CHRP, which was a legacy Cowen operating business prior to the Transactions. The Company's
	broker-dealer segment currently includes its investment banking, brokerage and equity research businesses.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
	Economic Income (Loss)
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The performance measure used by the Company for each segment is Economic Income (Loss), which management uses to evaluate the financial
	performance of and make operating decisions for the firm as a whole and each segment. Accordingly, management assesses its business by analyzing the performance of each segment and believes that
	investors should review the same performance measure that it uses to analyze its segment and business performance. In addition, management believes that Economic Income (Loss) is helpful to gain an
	understanding of its segment results of operations because it reflects such results on a consistent basis for all periods presented.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
	Economic Income (Loss) may not be comparable to similarly titled measures used by other companies. We use Economic Income (Loss) as a measure of each segment's operating performance,
	not as a measure of liquidity. Economic Income (Loss) should not be considered in isolation or as a substitute for operating income, net income, operating cash flows, investing and financing
	activities, or other income or cash flow statement data prepared in accordance with GAAP. As a result of the adjustments made to arrive at Economic Income (Loss), Economic Income (Loss) has
	limitations in that it does not take into account certain items included or excluded under GAAP, including our
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	62
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=7,SEQ=65,EFW="2202468",CP="COWEN GROUP, INC.",DN="1",CHK=621350,FOLIO='62',FILE='DISK121:[11ZAE1.11ZAE12801]DK12801A.;36',USER='JLAWRENA',CD='11-MAR-2011;19:26' -->
<A NAME="A2202468Z10-K_HTM_PAGE_DK12801_1_63">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A HREF="#A2202468Z10-K_HTM_BG12801A_MAIN_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<BR>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Consolidated
	Funds. Economic Income (Loss) is considered by management as a supplemental measure to the GAAP results to provide a more complete understanding of each segment's performance as measured
	by management. For a reconciliation of Economic Income to GAAP net income (loss) for the periods presented and additional information regarding the reconciling adjustments discussed above, see
	Note&nbsp;21 to the Company's audited consolidated financial statements included in this Form&nbsp;10-K.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
	general, Economic Income (Loss) is a pre-tax measure that (i)&nbsp;presents the Company's results of operations without the impact resulting from the consolidation of
	any of the Company's funds, (ii)&nbsp;excludes goodwill impairment (although there were no goodwill impairment charges in either period presented), (iii)&nbsp;excludes allocations to the managing
	member, as there will be no such allocations in the future (although there were no allocations made to the managing member in either period presented), and (iv)&nbsp;excludes the reorganization
	expenses for the Transactions (in the 2009 period only) and one-time equity awards made in connection with the Transactions (in the 2010 period only). In addition, Economic Income (Loss)
	revenues include investment income that represents the income the Company has earned in investing its own capital, including realized and unrealized gains and losses, interest and dividends, net of
	associated investment related expenses. For GAAP purposes, these items are included in each of their respective line items. Economic Income revenues also include management fees, incentive income and
	investment income earned through the Company's investment as a general partner in certain real estate entities. For GAAP purposes, all of these items are recorded in other income (loss). In addition,
	Economic Income (Loss) expenses are reduced by reimbursement from affiliates, which for GAAP purposes is presented gross as part of revenue.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Economic Income Revenues
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company's principal sources of Economic Income revenues are derived from activities in the following business segments:
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
	alternative investment management segment generates Economic Income revenues through three principal sources: management fees, incentive income and investment income from our own
	capital. Management fees are directly impacted by any increase or decrease in assets under management, while incentive income is impacted by our funds' performance and any increase or decrease in
	assets under
	management. Investment income from the Company's own capital is impacted by the performance of the funds and other securities in which our capital is invested, which is principally the Enterprise
	Fund. The Company periodically receives other Economic Income revenue which is unrelated to our own invested capital or our activities on behalf of the Company's funds, such as certain placement fee
	income received by a non-wholly owned subsidiary that engaged in the distribution of interests in the real estate funds.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
	broker-dealer segment generates Economic Income revenues through two principal sources: investment banking and brokerage. The Company earns investment banking revenue primarily from
	fees associated with public and private capital raising transactions and providing strategic advisory services. Investment banking revenues are derived primarily from small and
	mid-capitalization companies within the Company's target sectors of healthcare, technology, media and telecommunications, consumer, aerospace&nbsp;and defense, financial technology,
	REITs and alternative energy. The Company's brokerage revenues consist of commissions, principal transactions and fees paid for equity research. Management reviews brokerage revenue on a combined
	basis as the vast majority of the revenue is derived from the same group of clients. The Company derives its brokerage revenue primarily from trading equity and equity-linked securities on behalf of
	institutional investors. The majority of the Company's trading gains and losses are a result of activities that support the facilitation of client orders in both listed and
	over-the-counter securities, although all trading gains and losses are recorded in brokerage.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	63
</FONT>
</P>

<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A HREF="#A2202468Z10-K_HTM_BG12801A_MAIN_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Economic Income Expenses
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company's Economic Income expenses consist of compensation and benefits, non-compensation expenses&#151;fixed
	and non-compensation expenses&#151;variable, less reimbursement from affiliates.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Non-controlling Interests
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Non-controlling interests represent the pro rata share of the income or loss of the non-wholly owned
	consolidated entities attributable to the other owners of such entities. Non-wholly-owned entities included Ramius Alternative
	Solutions&nbsp;LLC, in the 2009 period only, as subsequent to the Transactions that entity became a wholly-owned subsidiary of the Company.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
	Year Ended December&nbsp;31, 2010 Compared with the Year Ended December&nbsp;31, 2009
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2010, the Company's alternative investment management segment includes twelve months of its
	hedge funds, replication products, mutual funds, managed futures fund, fund of funds, real estate funds, healthcare royalty funds, cash management services and other investment platforms operating
	results. In addition, the alternative investment management segment includes twelve months of CHRP's operating results for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2010, as a result of the Transactions. For
	the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2009, the Company's alternative investment management segment includes twelve months of its hedge funds, fund of funds, real estate and other investment platforms
	operating results. In addition, the alternative investment management segment includes two months of CHRP's operating results in 2009, as a result of the Transactions.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For
	the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2010, the Company's broker-dealer segment includes twelve months of its investment banking and brokerage businesses' operating results. For the
	year ended December&nbsp;31, 2009, the Company's broker-dealer segment includes two months of its investment banking and brokerage businesses' operating results as the historic results of operations
	reflect the legacy Ramius business only.
</FONT>
</P>

<B>
	$ Change

<TH STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=1>

<!-- ZEQ.=9,SEQ=67,EFW="2202468",CP="COWEN GROUP, INC.",DN="1",CHK=234347,FOLIO='64',FILE='DISK121:[11ZAE1.11ZAE12801]DK12801A.;36',USER='JLAWRENA',CD='11-MAR-2011;19:26' -->
<!-- THIS IS THE END OF A COMPOSITION COMPONENT -->
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A NAME="A2202468Z10-K_HTM_PAGE_DM12801_1_65">
</A>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_BASECOLOR,"BLACK" -->
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_DEFAULTFONT,"FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;" -->
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TABLESHADECOLOR,"#CCEEFF" -->
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_STABLERULES,"BORDER-BOTTOM:SOLID #000000 1.0PT;" -->
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_DTABLERULES,"BORDER-BOTTOM:DOUBLE #000000 2.25PT;" -->
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_SCRTABLERULES,"BORDER-BOTTOM:SOLID #000000 1.0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;" -->
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_DCRTABLERULES,"BORDER-BOTTOM:DOUBLE #000000 2.25PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;" -->
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A HREF="#A2202468Z10-K_HTM_BG12801A_MAIN_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Economic Income Revenues
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Total Economic Income revenues were $272.6&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2010, an increase of
	$171.8&nbsp;million compared to economic income revenues of $100.8&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2009.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Alternative Investment Management Segment
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Alternative investment management segment economic income revenues was $121.6&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31,
	2010, an increase of $49.2&nbsp;million compared to economic income revenues of $72.4&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2009.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Management Fees.
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Management fees for the segment decreased $2.5&nbsp;million, or 4.6%, to $51.4&nbsp;million for the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2010 compared with $53.9&nbsp;million for 2009. The decrease was a result of returning assets to investors in 2010, as a result of closing the Ramius Multi-Strategy Fund and the
	Enterprise Fund, and the return of assets to, and no longer charging management fees, to certain affiliates of UniCredit S.p.A effective July&nbsp;1, 2010, pursuant to the terms of the Modification
	Agreement. This was partially offset by increases in assets under management in our single-strategy funds.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Incentive Income (Loss).
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Incentive income for the segment increased $16.6&nbsp;million to $9.6&nbsp;million for the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2010 compared to a loss of $7.0&nbsp;million for 2009. The loss in the prior year was primarily due to a reversal of previously recorded incentive income allocations from
	Ramius's interests in the general partner of a certain real estate fund pursuant to the terms of the governing documents of such funds. The incentive income in 2010 is primarily a result of
	(i)&nbsp;the performance fees related to the Value and Opportunity fund surpassing its high-water marks, (ii)&nbsp;two fund of funds managed accounts that have also surpassed their
	high-water marks and hurdles during the year and (iii)&nbsp;the performance of the Global Credit fund.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Investment Income.
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Investment income for the segment increased $37.6&nbsp;million to $59.6&nbsp;million for the year ended
	December&nbsp;31,
	2010, compared to income of $22.0&nbsp;million for 2009. The increase is a result of revenue generated from the Luxembourg reinsurance service program and a general increase in performance in the
	Company's invested capital.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other Revenue.
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other revenue for the segment decreased $2.5&nbsp;million to $1.0&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2010,
	compared to $3.5&nbsp;million for 2009.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Broker-Dealer Segment
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Broker-dealer segment economic income revenues were $151.0&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2010, an increase of
	$122.6&nbsp;million compared to economic income revenues of $28.4&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2009. The increase was primarily attributable to the inclusion of only two
	months of the legacy Cowen Holdings brokerage revenues as compared to twelve months during 2010.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Investment Banking.
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Investment banking revenues increased $28.4&nbsp;million, or 269%, to $39.0&nbsp;million for the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2010 compared with $10.6&nbsp;million for 2009. The 2009 represents the investment banking activity of Cowen and Company for the period from November&nbsp;2, 2009 through
	December&nbsp;31, 2009. During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2010, the Company completed thirty one underwriting transactions, six private capital raising transactions and twelve strategic
	advisory transactions. During November and December of 2009, the Company completed five underwriting transactions, two private capital raising transactions and three strategic advisory transactions.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	65
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=68,EFW="2202468",CP="COWEN GROUP, INC.",DN="1",CHK=533164,FOLIO='65',FILE='DISK121:[11ZAE1.11ZAE12801]DM12801A.;29',USER='JLAWRENA',CD='11-MAR-2011;19:26' -->
<A NAME="A2202468Z10-K_HTM_PAGE_DM12801_1_66">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A HREF="#A2202468Z10-K_HTM_BG12801A_MAIN_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Brokerage.
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Brokerage revenues increased $94.4&nbsp;million, or 530%, to $112.2&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2010
	compared
	with $17.8&nbsp;million for 2009. The increase was primarily attributable to the inclusion of only two months of the legacy Cowen Holdings brokerage revenues as compared to twelve months during
	2010.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Economic Income Expenses
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Compensation and Benefits.
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Total compensation and benefits expense increased $92.7 million, or 99.4%, to $185.9&nbsp;million for the
	year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2010, compared with $93.2&nbsp;million in 2009. The increase was primarily attributable to the inclusion of only two months of legacy Cowen Holdings compensation and benefits
	expense during 2009.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Compensation
	and benefits expenses for the alternative investment management segment decreased $4.4&nbsp;million, or 6.9%, to $58.8&nbsp;million for the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2010 compared with $63.2&nbsp;million in 2009. The decrease was driven by lower accruals for incentive compensation and lower base salaries and benefit expense associated with a
	reduction in head count.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Compensation
	and benefits expenses for the broker-dealer segment increased $97.1&nbsp;million to $127.1&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2010 compared with
	$30.0&nbsp;million in 2009. The increase was primarily attributable to the inclusion of only two months of the legacy Cowen Holdings compensation and benefits expense during 2009 as compared to
	twelve months during 2010.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Non-compensation Expenses&#151;Fixed.
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Fixed non-compensation expenses increased $41.3&nbsp;million, or 78.2%, to
	$94.1&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2010 compared to $52.8&nbsp;million in 2009. The increase was primarily due to the inclusion of two months of fixed
	non-compensation expenses associated with the legacy Cowen Holdings business during 2009, partially offset by a decrease in non-compensation expense from the alternative
	investment management business.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Fixed
	non-compensation expenses for the alternative investment management segment decreased $12.0&nbsp;million, or 28.6%, to $29.9&nbsp;million for the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2010 compared with $41.9&nbsp;million in 2009. Fixed non-compensation expenses for the broker-dealer segment increased $53.4&nbsp;million to $64.3&nbsp;million
	for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2010 compared with $10.9&nbsp;million in 2009.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
	following table shows the components of the non-compensation expenses&#151;fixed, for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2010 and 2009:
</FONT>
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>

<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Non-compensation Expenses&#151;Variable.
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Variable non-compensation expenses, which primarily are comprised of expenses
	which are incurred as a direct result of the processing and soliciting of revenue generating activities, increased $26.6&nbsp;million to $33.7&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31,
	2010 compared to $7.1&nbsp;million in 2009. The increase was due to the inclusion of two months of variable
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	66
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=69,EFW="2202468",CP="COWEN GROUP, INC.",DN="1",CHK=635512,FOLIO='66',FILE='DISK121:[11ZAE1.11ZAE12801]DM12801A.;29',USER='JLAWRENA',CD='11-MAR-2011;19:26' -->
<A NAME="A2202468Z10-K_HTM_PAGE_DM12801_1_67">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A HREF="#A2202468Z10-K_HTM_BG12801A_MAIN_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<BR>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	non-compensation
	expenses associated with the legacy Cowen and Company business during 2009 related to Cowen and Company's investment banking and broker dealer businesses as compared to
	twelve months during 2010. During the fourth quarter of 2010, variable expenses of $4.3&nbsp;million were incurred related to Luxembourg reinsurance transactions, of which $3.3&nbsp;million
	related to transaction related costs, and $1.0&nbsp;million related to administrative costs.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
	following table shows the components of the non-compensation expenses&#151;variable, for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2010 and 2009:

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Reimbursement from Affiliates.
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Reimbursements from affiliates, which relate to the alternative investment
	management segment, decreased $3.7&nbsp;million, or 33.8%, to $7.3&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2010 compared with $11.0&nbsp;million in 2009. The decrease was mainly
	attributable to a decrease in AUM associated with the funds for which the Company receives the majority of its reimbursements.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Non-Controlling Interest.
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Non-Controlling interest represents the portion of the net income or loss attributable to certain
	non-wholly owned subsidiaries that is allocated to other investors.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
	Year Ended December&nbsp;31, 2009 Compared with the Year Ended December&nbsp;31, 2008
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In 2009, the Company's alternative investment management segment includes twelve months of its hedge funds, fund of funds, real estate
	and other investment platforms operating results. In addition, the alternative investment management segment includes two months of CHRP's operating results in 2009, as a result of the Transactions.
	In 2008, the Company's alternative investment management segment reflects twelve months of its hedge funds, fund of funds, real estate and other investment platforms operating results, but does not
	include any of CHRP's operating results.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	67
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>

<A NAME="A2202468Z10-K_HTM_PAGE_DM12801_1_68">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A HREF="#A2202468Z10-K_HTM_BG12801A_MAIN_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
	2009, the Company's broker-dealer segment includes two months of its investment banking and brokerage businesses' operating results. There were no investment banking nor brokerage
	operating results in 2008 as the historic results of operations only reflect the legacy Ramius business.
</FONT>
</P>

</TD>

<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Economic Income Revenues
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Total economic income revenues were $100.8&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2009, an increase of
	$119.7&nbsp;million compared to a revenue loss of $18.9&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2008.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Alternative Investment Management Segment
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Alternative investment management segment economic income revenues were $72.4&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31,
	2009, an increase of $91.3&nbsp;million compared to a revenue loss of $18.9&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2008.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Management Fees.
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Management fees for the segment decreased $30.7&nbsp;million, or 36%, to $53.9&nbsp;million for the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2009 compared with $84.6&nbsp;million for 2008. The decrease was due to the decrease in assets under management.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	68
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=71,EFW="2202468",CP="COWEN GROUP, INC.",DN="1",CHK=128040,FOLIO='68',FILE='DISK121:[11ZAE1.11ZAE12801]DM12801A.;29',USER='JLAWRENA',CD='11-MAR-2011;19:26' -->
<A NAME="A2202468Z10-K_HTM_PAGE_DM12801_1_69">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A HREF="#A2202468Z10-K_HTM_BG12801A_MAIN_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Incentive Income (Loss).
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Incentive loss for the segment increased $4.4&nbsp;million to a loss of $7.0&nbsp;million for the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2009 compared to a loss of $2.6&nbsp;million for 2008 primarily as a result of an increase in a reversal, in the current year period, of previously recorded incentive income
	allocations from Ramius's interests in the general partner of a certain real estate fund pursuant to the terms of the governing documents of such fund. In addition, as of December&nbsp;31, 2009
	there was a $4.5&nbsp;million accrual pertaining to subordination agreements entered into by the general partners of two real estate funds with those funds' lead investor. Furthermore, many of the
	funds now have high-water marks so that Ramius will not earn incentive income with respect to the investments of the fund investors who suffered such losses last year until the investors
	recover their losses.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Investment Income.
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Investment income for the segment increased $127.0&nbsp;million, or 121%, to a gain of $22.0&nbsp;million for the
	year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2009, compared with a loss of $105.0&nbsp;million for 2008. The increase is a result of positive fund performance in the current year period versus negative performance in the
	prior year period as a result of the general unprecedented levels of market volatility, and liquidity constraints that began in the third quarter of 2008 that affected almost every asset class
	globally.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other Revenue.
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other revenue for the segment decreased $0.5&nbsp;million, or 12%, to $3.5&nbsp;million for the year ended
	December&nbsp;31,
	2009, compared with $4.0&nbsp;million for 2008. The decrease was primarily due to the elimination of stock loan fee income as Ramius exited that business in the fourth quarter of 2008, and the
	elimination of placement fee income. Ramius exited the placement agent business in the third quarter of 2009.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Broker-Dealer Segment
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Broker-dealer segment economic income revenues were $28.4&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2009. There were no
	broker-dealer segment revenues in 2008 as the historic results of operations only reflect the legacy Ramius business.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Investment Banking.
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Investment banking revenues were $10.6&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2009, representing the
	investment
	banking activity of Cowen and Company for the period from November&nbsp;2, 2009 through December&nbsp;31, 2009. During November and December of 2009, the Company completed 5 underwriting
	transactions, 2 private capital raising transactions and 3 strategic advisory transactions. There were no investment banking revenues in 2008 as the historic results of operations only reflect the
	legacy Ramius business.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Brokerage.
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Brokerage revenues were $17.8&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2009, representing the brokerage activity of
	Cowen and
	Company for the period from November&nbsp;2, 2009 through December&nbsp;31, 2009. There were no brokerage revenues in 2008 as the historic results of operations only reflect the legacy Ramius
	business.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Economic Income Expenses
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Compensation and Benefits.
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Total compensation and benefits expense increased to $93.2&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31,
	2009, an
	increase of $8.4&nbsp;million compared to $84.8&nbsp;million in 2008. The increase was attributable to the inclusion of two months of legacy Cowen and Company compensation and benefits expense in
	2009.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Compensation
	and benefits expenses for the alternative investment management segment decreased $21.6&nbsp;million, or 25%, to $63.2&nbsp;million for the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2009 compared with $84.8&nbsp;million in the prior year period. The decrease was driven by lower accruals for incentive compensation and lower base salaries and benefit expense
	associated with a reduction in head count.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	69
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=72,EFW="2202468",CP="COWEN GROUP, INC.",DN="1",CHK=307886,FOLIO='69',FILE='DISK121:[11ZAE1.11ZAE12801]DM12801A.;29',USER='JLAWRENA',CD='11-MAR-2011;19:26' -->
<A NAME="A2202468Z10-K_HTM_PAGE_DM12801_1_70">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A HREF="#A2202468Z10-K_HTM_BG12801A_MAIN_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Compensation
	and benefits expenses for the broker-dealer segment were $30.0&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2009, which represents two months of operations of
	legacy Cowen. There were no broker-dealer segment compensation and benefits expenses in 2008 as the historic results of operations only reflect the legacy Ramius business.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Non-compensation Expenses&#151;fixed.
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Non-compensation expenses for the alternative investment management segment were
	$41.9&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2009. Non-compensation expenses for the broker-dealer segment were $10.9&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31,
	2009, which represents two months of legacy Cowen Holdings. The following table shows the components of the non-compensation expenses, in total, for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2009
	and 2008.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>

</TABLE>
</DIV>
<!-- END OF USER-SPECIFIED TAGGED TABLE -->
</DIV>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Non-compensation Expenses&#151;Variable.
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Variable non-compensation expenses, which primarily are comprised of expenses
	which are incurred as a direct result of the processing and soliciting of revenue generating activities, increased $3.1&nbsp;million to $7.1&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31,
	2009 compared to $4&nbsp;million in the prior year. The increase was due to the inclusion of two months variable non-compensation expenses associated with the legacy Cowen Holdings
	business during 2009 related to Cowen Holdings investment banking and broker dealer businesses and was offset by a reduction in variable non-compensation expenses in the Alternative
	Investment management business.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
	following table shows the components of the non-compensation expenses&#151;variable, for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2009 and 2008:
</FONT>
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_14"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PADDING:0PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;WIDTH:80%;MARGIN-LEFT:10%;">

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Reimbursement from Affiliates.
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Reimbursements from affiliates, which relate to the alternative investment management segment, decreased
	$6.4&nbsp;million, or 37%, to $11.0&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2009 compared with $17.4&nbsp;million for 2008. The decrease was attributable to lower assets under
	management in the 2009 period as such allocations are largely made based on a percentage of assets under management.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	70
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=6,SEQ=73,EFW="2202468",CP="COWEN GROUP, INC.",DN="1",CHK=573701,FOLIO='70',FILE='DISK121:[11ZAE1.11ZAE12801]DM12801A.;29',USER='JLAWRENA',CD='11-MAR-2011;19:26' -->
<A NAME="A2202468Z10-K_HTM_PAGE_DM12801_1_71">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A HREF="#A2202468Z10-K_HTM_BG12801A_MAIN_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Non-Controlling Interest.
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Non-Controlling interest represents the portion of the net income or loss attributable to certain
	non-wholly owned subsidiaries that is allocated to other investors.
</FONT>
</P>
</EFX_RESULTS_OF_OPERATIONS>
<EFX_LIQUIDITY_CAPITAL>
<A NAME="FIS_LIQUIDITY_CAPITAL"></A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Liquidity and Capital Resources
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We continually monitor our liquidity position. The working capital needs of the Company's business have been met through current levels
	of equity capital, current cash and cash equivalents, and anticipated cash generated from our operating activities, including management fees, incentive income, returns on the Company's own capital,
	investment banking fees and brokerage commissions. The Company expects that its primary working capital liquidity needs over the next twelve months will be to:
</FONT>
</P>
<UL>
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	pay our operating expenses, primarily consisting of compensation and benefits and general and administrative expenses;
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	repay borrowings and related interest expense; and
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	provide capital to facilitate the growth of our existing business.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
</UL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Based
	on our historical results, management's experience, our current business strategy and current assets under management, the Company believes that its existing cash resources will be
	sufficient to meet its anticipated working capital and capital expenditure requirements for at least the next twelve months. Our cash reserves include cash, cash equivalents and assets readily
	convertible into cash such
	as our securities held in inventory. Securities inventories are stated at fair value and are generally readily marketable. As of December&nbsp;31, 2010, we had cash and cash equivalents of
	$36.4&nbsp;million, which includes $12.4&nbsp;million held in foreign subsidiaries, and net liquid investment assets of $233&nbsp;million. At December&nbsp;31, 2010, the Company's investment
	in the Enterprise Fund was valued at $153.6&nbsp;million. The Company received total distributions of $142.4&nbsp;million from the Enterprise Fund during 2010 which includes the January&nbsp;1,
	2011 redemption of $12.5&nbsp;million. On September&nbsp;29, 2011, the Company will need to repay all amounts outstanding under the loan facility.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
	timing of cash bonus payments to our employees may significantly affect our cash position and liquidity from period to period. While our employees are generally paid salaries
	bi-weekly during the year, cash bonus payments, which can make up a significant portion of total compensation, are generally paid once a year in February.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
	discussed in "Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations&#151;Certain Factors Impacting Our Business" we have entered into a
	modification agreement with affiliates of Unicredit S.p.A. It is not expected to have a material impact on the Company's liquidity and capital resources.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
	of December&nbsp;31, 2010, the Company had unfunded commitments of $8.3&nbsp;million pertaining to capital commitments in three real estate investments held by the Company, all of
	which pertain to related party investments. Such commitments can be called at any time, subject to advance notice. In addition, the Company has committed to invest $40.7&nbsp;million in CHRP Funds
	as a limited partner of the CHRP Funds and also as a member of Cowen Healthcare Royalty&nbsp;GP,&nbsp;LLC, the general partner of the CHRP Funds. This commitment is expected to be called over a
	two to five year period. The Company will make its pro-rata investment in the CHRP Funds along with the other limited partners. Through December&nbsp;31, 2010, the Company has funded
	$18.9&nbsp;million towards these commitments.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
	a registered broker-dealer, Cowen and Company is subject to the SEC's Uniform Net Capital Rule&nbsp;15c3-1 (the "Rule"), which requires the maintenance of minimum net
	capital. Under the alternative method permitted by the Rule, Cowen and Company's minimum net capital requirement, as defined, is $1.0&nbsp;million. Cowen and Company is not permitted to withdraw
	equity if certain minimum net capital requirements are not met. As of December&nbsp;31, 2010, Cowen and Company had total net
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	71
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=7,SEQ=74,EFW="2202468",CP="COWEN GROUP, INC.",DN="1",CHK=832342,FOLIO='71',FILE='DISK121:[11ZAE1.11ZAE12801]DM12801A.;29',USER='JLAWRENA',CD='11-MAR-2011;19:26' -->
<A NAME="A2202468Z10-K_HTM_PAGE_DM12801_1_72">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A HREF="#A2202468Z10-K_HTM_BG12801A_MAIN_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<BR>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	capital
	of approximately $27.7&nbsp;million, which was approximately $26.7&nbsp;million in excess of its minimum net capital requirement of $1.0&nbsp;million.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cowen
	and Company is exempt from the provisions of Rule&nbsp;15c3-3 under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 as their activities are limited to those set forth in the
	conditions for exemption appearing in paragraph&nbsp;(k)(2)(ii) of the Rule.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Proprietary
	accounts of introducing brokers ("PAIB") held at the clearing broker are considered allowable assets for net capital purposes, pursuant to agreements between Cowen and
	Company and the clearing broker, which require, among other things, that the clearing broker performs computations for PAIB and segregates certain balances on behalf of Cowen and Company, if
	applicable.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Ramius
	UK&nbsp;Ltd. ("Ramius UK") and Cowen International Limited ("CIL") are subject to the capital requirements of the Financial Services Authority ("FSA") of the UK.
	Financial Resources, as defined, must exceed the total Financial Resources requirement of the FSA. At December&nbsp;31, 2010, Ramius UK's Financial Resources of $3.8&nbsp;million exceeded its
	minimum requirement of $0.4&nbsp;million by $3.4&nbsp;million. At December&nbsp;31, 2010, CIL's Financial Resources of $5.1&nbsp;million exceeded its minimum requirement of
	$2.7&nbsp;million by $2.4&nbsp;million.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cowen
	Latitude Advisors Limited ("CLAL") is subject to the financial resources requirements of the Securities and Futures Commission ("SFC") of Hong Kong. Financial
	Resources, as defined, must exceed the Total Financial Resources requirement of the SFC. At December&nbsp;31, 2010, CLAL's Financial Resources of $0.8&nbsp;million exceeded the
	minimum requirement of $0.1&nbsp;million by $0.7&nbsp;million.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
	Company may also incur additional indebtedness or raise additional capital under certain circumstances to respond to market opportunities and challenges. Current market conditions
	may make it more difficult or costly to borrow additional funds or raise additional capital. In addition, our secured revolving credit facility with UniCredit Bank AG (formerly known as Bayerische
	Hypo-und Vereinsbank AG) ("HVB AG") referenced below prohibits us and certain of our subsidiaries from incurring any indebtedness, other than certain indebtedness permitted under the
	facility.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
	Cash Flows Analysis
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company's primary sources of cash are derived from its operating activities, fees, realized returns on its own invested capital and
	borrowings under its line of credit. The Company's primary uses of cash include compensation, general and administrative expenses and payments of interest and principal under its line of credit. Cash
	flow results during the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2008 only reflect the cash flows and net loss of Ramius&nbsp;LLC prior to the Transactions. The cash flow results during the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2009 only include the cash flows of the legacy Cowen Holdings business for two months. As a result, the cash flow amounts from operating, investing and financing activities for the
	year ended December&nbsp;31, 2010, 2009, and 2008 are not comparable.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating Activities.
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net cash used in operating activities of $51.6&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2010 was
	predominately
	related to cash payments for purchases of securities related the Company's invested capital and Consolidated Funds offset partially by proceeds from sales of securities owned by the Company and the
	Consolidated Funds. Net cash provided by operating activities of $110.3&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2009 was predominately related to cash acquired upon the completion of the
	Transactions, proceeds from sales of securities and sales of other investments, partially offset by a net cash loss and purchases of securities owned. Net cash used in operating activities of
	$96.7&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2008 was predominately related to a net cash loss, partially offset by the reduction in securities owned and fees receivable. In 2008, the
	Company wound down its securities lending operation which resulted in a significant change in receivables from brokers mostly offset by a corresponding change in payable to brokers.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	72
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=8,SEQ=75,EFW="2202468",CP="COWEN GROUP, INC.",DN="1",CHK=57706,FOLIO='72',FILE='DISK121:[11ZAE1.11ZAE12801]DM12801A.;29',USER='JLAWRENA',CD='11-MAR-2011;19:26' -->
<A NAME="A2202468Z10-K_HTM_PAGE_DM12801_1_73">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A HREF="#A2202468Z10-K_HTM_BG12801A_MAIN_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Investing Activities.
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net cash used in investing activities of $109.5&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2010 was
	primarily from
	the purchase of other investments related to the Company's invested capital and increased reverse repurchase agreement activity. Net cash provided by investing activities of $8.9&nbsp;million for
	the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2009 was primarily due to the proceeds from sale of other investments. Net cash used in investing activities of $16.1&nbsp;million for the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2008 was primarily due to the purchase of fixed assets related to the relocation of the Company's headquarters into new office space.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Financing Activities.
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net cash provided by financing activities for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2010 was $50&nbsp;million
	primarily related
	to increased repurchase agreement activity partially offset by a repayment on the line of credit and payments by the Consolidated Funds for capital withdrawals. For the year ended December&nbsp;31,
	2009 net cash used in financing activities was $18.5&nbsp;million, the financing activities excluding the consolidated entities provided net cash of $80.6&nbsp;million due to proceeds from a
	capital raising event in December 2009 which was partially offset by capital withdrawals of $23.9&nbsp;million, which were mostly redeemed prior to the Transactions, and $10.4&nbsp;million used to
	purchase the 50% interest in Ramius Alternative Solutions. For the twelve months ended December&nbsp;31, 2008 net cash provided by financing activities was $141.6&nbsp;million, however, the
	financing activities excluding the consolidated entities used net cash of $11.7&nbsp;million primarily driven by a net withdrawal of $21&nbsp;million of member's capital.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Short-Term Borrowings and other debt
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On June&nbsp;3, 2009, the Company entered into a collateralized revolving credit agreement with HVB AG, as lender, administrative
	agent and issuing bank, providing for a revolving credit facility with a $50.0&nbsp;million aggregate loan commitment amount available, with a $7.0&nbsp;million letter of credit
	sub-limit. As of December&nbsp;31, 2010 and December&nbsp;31, 2009, the Company had borrowings of $24.0&nbsp;million and $43.0&nbsp;million, respectively, under the line of credit
	portion. The Company also had a letter of credit of $6.7&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2009 with HVB AG. At the Company's election and discretion, borrowings under this collateralized
	revolving credit agreement bear interest per annum (based on a 360&nbsp;day year) equal to either: (a)&nbsp;0.5% plus the greater of (1)&nbsp;the lender's prime rate, (2)&nbsp;the overnight
	federal funds rate plus 0.5% and (3)&nbsp;the LIBOR rate plus 1.0% or (b)&nbsp;the LIBOR rate plus 2.75%. Due to the variable interest rate on these borrowings, their carrying values approximate
	fair value. The Company is required to pay a quarterly commitment fee on the undrawn portion of the revolving credit facility equal to 1.0% per annum of the undrawn amount. For letters of credit, the
	Company will pay a fee on the stated amount of the letter of credit at a rate equal to 2.75%. The 2009 collateralized revolving credit agreement was to mature on November&nbsp;2, 2009 but was
	extended; $25.0&nbsp;million was extended through January&nbsp;4, 2010 and $25&nbsp;million was extended through September&nbsp;29, 2011. All terms of the extended collateralized revolving
	credit agreement remain the same except the following: at the Company's election and discretion, borrowings under the extended 2009 collateralized revolving credit agreement bear interest per annum
	(based on a 360&nbsp;day year) equal to either: (1)&nbsp;the lender's prime rate plus 1.5% or (2)&nbsp;the 1, 2 or 3&nbsp;month LIBOR rate plus 3.5%. For letters of credit, the Company will
	pay a fee on the stated amount of the letter of credit at a rate equal to 3.5%. The 2009 collateralized revolving credit agreement contained financial and other restrictive covenants that limited the
	Company's ability to incur additional debt and engage in other activities. As of December&nbsp;31, 2010 and during the period from June&nbsp;3, 2009 to December&nbsp;31, 2010, the Company was in
	compliance with these covenants.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	73
</FONT>
</P>

<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A HREF="#A2202468Z10-K_HTM_BG12801A_MAIN_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During 2010, HVB AG notified us that they will not be renewing the $6.7&nbsp;million letter of credit which supports the lease of office space in New York. The
	Company has replaced that letter of credit with a new letter of credit by another financial institution which expires December&nbsp;12, 2011.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
	January&nbsp;4, 2010, in accordance with the terms of the collateralized revolving credit agreement, the Company remitted $25&nbsp;million to HVB AG, reducing its revolving line
	of credit balance.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Interest
	incurred on the Company's lines of credit (in combination with all previous lines of credit) for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2010, 2009 and 2008 was $1.0&nbsp;million,
	$1.5&nbsp;million and $1.5&nbsp;million, respectively.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cash
	collateral pledged at December&nbsp;31, 2009, on the consolidated statements of financial condition, represents collateral that was required to be posted for obligations or
	potential obligations under the letter of credit discussed above pursuant to the lease agreement for the Company's premises in New York City. This collateral was released with the terms of the
	extended collateralized revolving credit agreement. The Company's investment in Enterprise Master through the Enterprise Fund has been pledged as collateral under the line of credit portion of the
	revolving credit agreement discussed above.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
	November 2010, the Company borrowed $0.6&nbsp;million and $1.5&nbsp;million to fund insurance premium payments. These notes bear interest at 5.05% and 4.95%, respectively and are
	due in October of 2011. As of December&nbsp;31, 2010, the outstanding balance on these combined notes payable was $1.4&nbsp;million. Interest expense for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2010
	was not significant.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
	of December&nbsp;31, 2010 the Company also has four additional irrevocable letters of credit, for which there is cash collateral pledged, including (i)&nbsp;$50,000, which expires
	on July&nbsp;12, 2011, supporting workers' compensation insurance with Safety National Casualty Corporation, (ii)&nbsp;$57,000, which expires on May&nbsp;12, 2011, supporting Cowen Healthcare
	Royalty Management,&nbsp;LLC's Stamford office lease and (iii)&nbsp;$82,000, which expires on May&nbsp;12, 2011, supporting the Company's San Francisco office and (iv)&nbsp;$1.2&nbsp;million
	which expires on August&nbsp;31, 2011, supporting the Company's lease of additional office space in New York. To the extent any letter of credit is drawn upon, interest will be assessed at the prime
	commercial lending rate. As of December&nbsp;31, 2010 and December&nbsp;31, 2009, there were no amounts due related to these letters of credit.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Ramius
	Levered Multi-Strategy FOF&nbsp;LP had a $100.0&nbsp;million line of credit with a major financial institution with a minimum borrowing amount of $20.0&nbsp;million. Levered
	FOF could borrow on this line of credit up to 72% of the amount of collateral pledged. In accordance with the loan agreement, interest accrued on the loan as well as custodian and other fees incurred
	by Levered FOF in connection with the loan was capitalized and added to the total outstanding balance of the loan. During 2008, due to Levered FOF going into liquidation, the minimum borrowing amount
	was waived. As of December&nbsp;31, 2008, the outstanding balance on this line of credit was $10.0&nbsp;million. This loan bears interest at LIBOR plus 1.35% per annum. Due to the floating rate of
	interest, its carrying value approximates fair value. At December&nbsp;31, 2008, all investments owned by Levered FOF were pledged as collateral in connection with this line of credit. Interest
	incurred on Levered FOF's line of credit during the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2009 and 2008 was $0 and $1.6&nbsp;million, respectively. Levered FOF's line of credit was repaid in full as of
	February&nbsp;5, 2009 and was discontinued on that date.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	74
</FONT>
</P>
